Corresponds to 150 years after the start of the simulation (2021+150), reaching 10% decline.
Corresponds to 250 years after the start of the simulation (2021+250), peaking at 18% decline.
Welfare of generations born in 150 years (2171) is 6.5% lower than welfare of agents born today. The transition to clean energy takes 250 years and temperature increases by 4.5 degrees.
Welfare gains up to 3.5% for future generations born after 250 years (2271) with a 15% carbon tax.
Increase in temperature is 4.5 degrees after 250 years.
The result refers to a scenario after 200 years where there is an almost 30 percent reduction in GDP. No specific country is mentioned, and the outcome is under worst-case scenario.

While aggregate consumption can be reduced by more than one third during consumption disasters, these events account for approximately 1% of the time and are not permanent. This is due to the assumption that 60% of CO2 is permanent in the atmosphere, with 40% slowly depreciating over time.
Generations born 200 years into the future gain 1.5% in consumption equivalence with the implementation of a 25% optimal fixed carbon tax rate on dirty energy.
Current and near-future generations gain about 0.1 to 0.5% in consumption equivalence with the implementation of a 25% optimal fixed carbon tax rate on dirty energy. Using midpoint of range.
In about 175 years (which corresponds to around 325 years from present), the welfare gains are approximately 1.3%.
The implementation of a 25% carbon-tax rate makes climate disasters very unlikely, with a probability below 0.5%.
In 5000 simulated paths, only one climate disaster occurred, indicating a very low probability of climate disasters occurring under the scenario.
